lg.l: The sun has rose, and, through the morning haze,
He fiercely shoots his penetrating rays;
The wind’s impetuous rush, with sultry breath,
From wastes where desolation reigns—and death;
The crackling fires Fires. The Illawarra Mercury reported on 22 February 1858 that areas of inland New South Wales had been visited by bush fires (p. 2). sweep o’er the forest wide,
Illume the ravine, scale the mountain side,
And thund’ring down come many a gum and oak
That never felt the brawny axe-man’s stroke.
Anon—as if to mock the expectant eye—
The EMPTY clouds expand along the sky,
Still, by conflicting currents, deviously driven,
And dissipated in the wastes of Heaven.

The stream is failing Stream is failing. The Illawarra Mercury also reported on 22 February 1858 that numerous creeks are entirely dry, and there is less water in the river than can be remembered at any former period by the oldest inhabitants (p. 2). at the fountain head,
And faintly ripples down its stoney bed;
And where the uncertain waters were wont to run,
The smooth, brown pebbles glow ‘neath the scorching sun;
The thirsty cattle seek the cooling brook,
But turn away, unslaked, with languid look;
The damps that fertilised the soil exhale,
And all its fructifying powers fail;
The fields have changed their gay, green summer gown
For an undress of shabby russet-brown;
The enchanting landscape, where the light and shade,
By turns, its varied beauties best displayed,
Though nurs’d and rear’d in Nature’s very arms,
Spreads out deflower’d and spoil’d of half its charms;
The tender clovers long have ceas’d to bloom
And load the balmy air with rich perfume;
No more the wild bee murmurs o’er the sod:
And Nature’s self would mar the works of GOD,
But, see! the Heavens put on a lurid look;
And hark! the earth is to its centre shook.
Flash crosses flash, and peal on peal is hurl’d—
So loud might be the ‘larm-bell of the world.
I haste! I fly! I seek the friendly roof.
The drought is past—when Heaven shall show the proof.
